items.prompt: At work, A colleague says, "If launch quality is high, QA pass rate rises. QA pass rate rose, so launch quality must be high." What is the best next move?
options: Use a structural check and test disconfirming evidence before concluding
Trust the first plausible pattern and proceed
Rely on confidence and skip formal checks
Use one anecdote as proof
items.why_right: The structural/disconfirming check prevents this specific reasoning failure.
why_traps: Plausibility alone is not sufficient evidence.

why_traps: Plausibility alone is not sufficient evidence.

items.prompt: In a study context, A manager says the new ritual caused better outcomes because both rose this month. What is the best next move?
options: Use a structural check and test disconfirming evidence before concluding
Trust the first plausible pattern and proceed
Rely on confidence and skip formal checks
Use one anecdote as proof
items.why_right: The structural/disconfirming check prevents this specific reasoning failure.
why_traps: Plausibility alone is not sufficient evidence.

items.prompt: In a study context, You are asked to transfer a tactic from one project to another that only looks similar. What is the best next move?
options: Use a structural check and test disconfirming evidence before concluding
Trust the first plausible pattern and proceed
Rely on confidence and skip formal checks
Use one anecdote as proof
items.why_right: The structural/disconfirming check prevents this specific reasoning failure.
why_traps: Plausibility alone is not sufficient evidence.

items.prompt: You think: "If the client is happy, they will reply today." No reply arrives. What is the best conclusion?
options: The client is unhappy
No reply does not prove the client is unhappy
The project is definitely off track
They are ignoring you on purpose
items.why_right: A missing reply does not prove the opposite. You need a clearer signal before concluding anything.
why_traps: No reply can happen for many reasons.
Project status cannot be inferred from a single missing message.

items.prompt: You believe: "If the new meeting format works, we will finish on time." What would most change your mind that it is working?
options: One meeting ends on time
Several meetings end on time across the week, compared with before
Someone says it feels smoother
You feel less stressed afterward
items.why_right: A pattern across several meetings is a stronger test than a single instance or feelings.
why_traps: One meeting can be a fluke.
Stress can change for unrelated reasons.

items.prompt: You think: "If I understand this topic, I will get every practice question right." You miss one question. What is the best conclusion?
options: You do not understand the topic at all
One wrong answer does not prove you do not understand the topic
You should abandon the topic and move on
The practice questions are useless
items.why_right: Understanding is not all-or-nothing. A single miss can reflect a detail gap, misread question, or time pressure.
why_traps: Over-generalising from one miss is a common error.
Practice questions can still be useful even if imperfect.

items.prompt: You believe: "If this study method works, my recall will improve." What would most change your mind that it works?
options: One good revision session
Better recall across several sessions, checked the same way each time
You enjoy the method more
A friend recommends it
items.why_right: Repeated checks using the same measure are a stronger test than a single session, enjoyment, or opinions.
why_traps: Enjoyment is not the same as improved recall.
Other people's preferences may not match yours.

items.prompt: A colleague says: "This team always misses deadlines." What is the best next move?
options: Agree. Always is probably true
Ask for one clear example where they met a deadline, or why they did not
Change the topic to keep things calm
Assume it is true because they sound confident
items.why_right: Looking for an exception or concrete example tests whether always is accurate and reveals causes.
why_traps: Strong language often hides missing detail.
Avoiding the topic does not improve accuracy.

items.prompt: You believe: "This process is the best way to do it." What would most change your mind?
options: A single person dislikes it
A clear case where the process fails under a known condition (time pressure, missing data, scale)
A longer document describing the process
A new name for the process
items.why_right: A specific failure condition is a real counterexample and tells you when to switch approach.
why_traps: More description is not evidence of effectiveness.

items.prompt: You think: "Flashcards always work for learning." What is the best next move?
options: Keep using them no matter what
Ask: when do flashcards fail (for example, complex explanations or problem-solving), and what to use instead?
Stop all revision methods
Only use flashcards for everything
items.why_right: Looking for exceptions helps you choose the right method for the right content, rather than over-using one tool.
why_traps: One tool rarely fits every situation.
Stopping everything is not a reasoned response.
Over-applying a tool creates avoidable failure.

items.prompt: You believe: "I learn best by re-reading." What would most change your mind?
options: A teacher says re-reading is bad
Seeing that recall tests improve more when you practise retrieval than when you re-read
A nicer textbook layout
Studying longer hours
items.why_right: A direct comparison using the same recall test is strong evidence that can overturn a belief about best.
why_traps: Authority alone is not a test.

items.prompt: One user reports a serious bug. You feel the release is unsafe. What is the best next move?
options: Assume the release is unsafe based on one report
Check how often this bug type happens overall and how many users are affected
Ignore the report because it is only one person
Blame the user's device without checking
items.why_right: Base rates prevent overreacting to one vivid case. You need the wider frequency to judge risk.
why_traps: One report can be important but not representative.
Ignoring evidence is also an error.

items.prompt: A colleague says a new tool doubled productivity. What would most change your mind that it genuinely helps?
options: Another single colleague says the same
Seeing similar gains across several people compared with normal week-to-week variation
A longer feature list
A convincing brand name
items.why_right: Multiple cases compared with baseline variation is stronger evidence than anecdotes or marketing.
why_traps: Two anecdotes are still weak evidence.
Features and branding do not show outcomes.
Claims can be inflated without comparison.

items.prompt: You read one dramatic story about a study technique failing and assume it is useless. What is the best next move?
options: Assume it never works
Check how often it works on average and in what conditions
Ignore all evidence and use your gut
Only trust dramatic stories
items.why_right: Base rates help you avoid being swayed by vivid single cases and focus on typical outcomes.
why_traps: Gut feelings are not a frequency estimate.

items.prompt: You think you failed because you got one low score on a quiz. What would most change your mind about your overall progress?
options: One friend says you are doing fine
Your average score across several quizzes improves over time
You feel more motivated today
You read the notes again
items.why_right: Progress is best judged by trends over repeated checks, not one score or feelings.
why_traps: Re-reading does not show recall improvement by itself.

items.prompt: You notice you feel focused on days you start early. You assume starting early causes focus. What is the best next move?
options: Conclude early start causes focus
Try starting early for a short run while keeping other factors as steady as possible
Read more opinions about early mornings
Assume focus is just random
items.why_right: A small intervention test is stronger than assuming cause from a pattern you observed.
why_traps: Patterns can be driven by hidden factors (sleep, stress, deadlines).
Randomness is not a conclusion without checking.

items.prompt: You believe a new workflow improves quality. What evidence would most change your mind?
options: One day quality feels worse
A short A/B trial showing no improvement compared with the old workflow
A colleague complains
The workflow looks more professional
items.why_right: A direct comparison trial is strong evidence about cause and effect.

items.prompt: You notice you do better when you study with music. You assume music causes better learning. What is the best next move?
options: Assume music is the cause
Try a short run with and without music while checking recall the same way
Tell everyone music is essential
Stop studying without music forever
items.why_right: Testing with and without music using the same recall check is a simple way to test cause rather than coincidence.
why_traps: Universal claims rarely follow from one person's experience.

items.prompt: You believe late-night study works best for me. What would most change your mind?
options: A friend prefers mornings
A short comparison where your recall is better after earlier study for the same topic length
A motivational quote about mornings
A new desk lamp
items.why_right: A direct comparison using the same recall check tests what actually works for you.
why_traps: Other people's preferences do not test yours.
Motivation and tools are not evidence of learning.

items.prompt: You want to copy a strategy from another company because their situation sounds similar. What is the best next move?
options: Copy it exactly
Check the structure: goal, constraints, resources, and what actually drove success, then adapt
Ignore it completely
Only copy the parts that look impressive
items.why_right: Transfer works when you match the underlying structure, not surface similarity.
why_traps: Ignoring all examples throws away useful information.

items.prompt: You think: this project is basically the same as the last one. What would most change your mind?
options: It feels familiar
A key constraint is different (deadline, rules, resources) and changes what actions are possible
The branding is different
A different team member joins
items.why_right: A changed constraint changes the problem structure, so the old solution may no longer fit.
why_traps: Familiarity is a feeling, not a structural match.
Branding and people can matter, but constraints often determine what is possible.

items.prompt: You remember a similar-looking example and try to apply it, but you are not sure it truly matches. What is the best next move?
options: Apply it anyway because it looks similar
Identify the deep match: same relationship or rule, not just similar words
Avoid using examples at all
Memorise more examples without checking structure
items.why_right: Analogies work when the underlying relationship matches, not when the surface features match.
why_traps: Avoidance removes a useful learning tool.
More examples without structure increases confusion.

items.prompt: You think: this new topic is just like the last one. What would most change your mind?
options: The headings look similar
The key rule is different and changes what answers count as correct
The textbook font is different
The lecturer uses different slides
items.why_right: A different rule changes the structure, so the same approach may fail.
why_traps: Headings and presentation can be surface-level cues.
Style changes do not necessarily change the underlying rule.
